data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing optimization problem. Goal: pack n Christmas trees (n=1 to 200) into smallest square bounding box. Score = sum of (side^2/n) for all n. Trees are 15-vertex polygons with specific shape (trunk + 3-tier branches). Key techniques: 1) bbox3 binary optimizer for global optimization, 2) shake_public for local refinement, 3) fix_direction rotation tightening using convex hull and minimize_scalar, 4) overlap repair by replacing invalid groups with donor solutions

Key optimization approach: 1) Start with a good baseline submission, 2) Run bbox3 optimizer with different n/r parameters in phases (short runs to find promising settings, then longer runs on best candidates), 3) Apply fix_direction to tighten rotation using convex hull optimization, 4) Validate and repair overlaps by replacing invalid groups from donor file, 5) Use shake_public for additional local optimization

Key optimization algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing: 1) Genetic algorithms combined with linear programming, 2) Local search heuristics based on nonlinear programming, 3) Simulated annealing, 4) Tabu search, 5) Particle swarm optimization, 6) Jostle algorithm for efficient local search. Key techniques: separation algorithms using MTV (Minimum Translation Vector), convex hull optimization for rotation, bottom-left heuristics, and overlap minimization through iterative local search.

data_findings.finding: Additional optimization techniques from smartmanoj kernel: 1) Backward Propagation - remove trees from n-tree config to potentially improve (n-1)-tree config, 2) Multi-start with different angle restarts, 3) Swap moves between trees, 4) Squeeze operation - scale all trees toward center, 5) Compaction - move trees toward center in small steps, 6) Local search with 8-directional moves and rotation adjustments, 7) Simulated annealing with higher temperature

Additional optimization techniques: 1) Rotating Calipers method for computing Oriented Minimum Bounding Box (OMBB) - the smallest-area enclosing rectangle has a side collinear with one edge of the convex hull, 2) No-Fit Polygon (NFP) for generating candidate placements using Minkowski sum, 3) Branch-and-bound-and-prune for exact solutions, 4) Guided Cuckoo Search (GCS) - state-of-the-art heuristic combining piece clustering, NFP-based bottom-left heuristics, and overlap minimization

web_research.query: What are the best optimization algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing problems?
web_research.finding: For 2D irregular polygon packing problems, various optimization algorithms have been explored, with metaheuristic and hybrid approaches being particularly prominent. One effective method is a hybrid approach combining genetic algorithms with linear programming, which has been shown to optimize irregular packing efficiently ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)). Additionally, local search heuristics based on nonlinear programming have been successfully applied to irregular strip packing problems, often outperforming conventional heuristics in minimizing waste ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305054811001596)). Metaheuristic algorithms such as genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, and tabu search have also been reviewed extensively, with genetic algorithms being particularly popular due to their ability to explore large search spaces effectively ([Springer](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1012590107280)). web_research.query: What are the best techniques for minimizing bounding box in 2D polygon packing with rotation?
web_research.finding:
Minimizing the bounding box in 2D polygon packing with rotation involves several advanced techniques aimed at reducing the overall area while ensuring polygons do not overlap. One of the most effective approaches is the use of exact algorithms such as branch-and-bound methods, which systematically explore possible placements and rotations to find the optimal solution. For instance, a parallel branch-and-bound-and-prune algorithm has been proposed for irregular strip packing with discrete rotations, which employs bounding techniques and conflict graphs to prune the search space efficiently ([arXiv](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.21009)). These algorithms often incorporate geometric computations like the minimum-area oriented bounding box (OMBB), which can be calculated using the rotating calipers method on the convex hull of the polygons, leading to tighter bounding boxes ([geidav.wordpress.com](https://geidav.wordpress.com/2014/01/23/computing-oriented-minimum-bounding-boxes-in-2d)).
